row.entry: These rules permit a party to make voluntary written admissions. They also provide a notice procedure whereby parties can require admissions in relation to specified facts or documents.
This rule sets out the admissions imputed by discovery. It also requires discovered documents to be available for production at the trial of proceedings.
This rule limits the effect of admissions to the conduct of the proceedings in which they are made.
This rule permits a party to obtain judgment giving effect to admissions made in their favour.

This Part applies to all courts in Schedule 1 of the CPA, except in relation to proceedings in the Local Court, Small Claims Division and the Industrial Commission (when constituted otherwise than as the Industrial Court) (except to the extent to which the Commission orders that the Part is to apply): see r 1.5 and Sch 1.

The Part is based on, and substantially reproduces, the former SCR Part 18, DCR Part 15 and LCR Part 14. The Part complements the court’s powers in s 70 of the CP Act (informal proof) and r 2.3(e) of UCPR, as well as the interrogatory procedure provided for in rr 22.1–22.6.
Admissions, by failure to dispute notice ‥ [r 17.3(2)] , [r 17.4(2)]
Admissions made otherwise than in the formal course of proceedings ‥ [17.2.10]
Pleadings and evidence in other proceedings ‥ [17.7.40]
Production of discovered documents at trial ‥ [17.5.5]
Time for disputing notice to admit ‥ [r 17.3(2)] , [r 17.4(2)]
Withdrawal of formal admissions made in the proceedings ‥ [17.2.5]

p.text: In this Part, other than rule 17.5:
means a party who is admitting, or being asked to admit, any matter.
means a party in whose favour another party is admitting, or being asked to admit, any matter.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 17.2] r 17.2 Voluntary admissions of fact (cf SCR Part 18, rule 1; DCR Part 15, rule 1; LCR Part 14, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Voluntary admissions of fact (cf SCR Part 18, rule 1; DCR Part 15, rule 1; LCR Part 14, rule 1)

p.text: The admitting party may, by a notice served on the requesting party, admit, in favour of the requesting party only and for the purposes of the proceedings only, the facts specified in the notice.
The admitting party may, with the leave of the court, withdraw any such admission.

level.toc-caption: [17.2.5] Withdrawal of formal admissions made in the proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [17.2.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 191.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 56–58.

heading.title: Withdrawal of formal admissions made in the proceedings

p.text: Formal admissions may be either express or deemed. Express formal admissions can be made in pleadings, in separate notices under r 17.2 , or in response to notices under UCPR rr 17.3 and 17.4 . They can also be made orally in the course of the hearing of the proceedings: Urquhart v Butterfield (1887) 37 Ch D 357 at 369, 374 ; McFadden v Snow (1952) 69 WN (NSW) 8 at 9 . Deemed formal admissions arise where a party fails to traverse a pleaded allegation (see r 14.26 ) or fails to respond timeously to notices under rr 17.3 and 17.4 . Pursuant to r 17.6 such an admission operates only in favour of the party in whose favour it was made, and is taken to have been made only for the purpose of the particular proceedings: Nominal Defendant v Gabriel (2007) 71 NSWLR 150; 48 MVR 31; [2007] NSWCA 52; BC200701991 at [110] . But once such a formal admission has been made the factual issue is foreclosed in the proceedings and no evidence may be led, or submission made, controverting the admitted fact: see also Evidence Act 1995 s 191 .

Any formal admission made under these various provisions of the Rules can be withdrawn, but only with leave: see rr 12.6 , 17.2(2) , 17.3(3) and 17.4(3) and Nominal Defendant v Gabriel (2007) 71 NSWLR 150; 48 MVR 31; [2007] NSWCA 52; BC200701991 at [109] (admission made by counsel at trial).

The discretion to grant leave to withdraw a formal admission is stated in general terms. Its exercise therefore attracts the provisions of CPA ss 56–58 (ie, “overriding purpose” and “dictates of justice”). Consistent with the potentially relevant factors mandated by those provisions, an applicant for leave must establish proper grounds for withdrawal of the admission: Langdale v Danby [1982] 3 All ER 129; [1982] 1 WLR 1123 at 1134 ; Rigato Farms Pty Ltd v Ridolfi [2001] 2 Qd R 455; [2000] QCA 292; BC200004236 ; SLE Worldwide Australia Pty Ltd v Wyatt Gallagher Bassett Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 816; BC200505863 at [57], [62] and [65] (Wyatt Gallagher Bassett) which sets out various relevant extracts from the case law on this issue. What constitutes proper grounds in any particular case will necessarily depend on the nature of the admission and the stage of the proceedings when the application is made. It will ordinarily require explanation of the circumstances in which the admission was made and those relied on to justify the withdrawal: Maile v Rafiq [2005] NSWCA 410; BC200510054 at [42], [56] and [74]–[77]; Silver v Dome Resources NL [2005] NSWSC 265; BC200501651 at [8]–[10] (Dome Resources); Jeans v Commonwealth Bank of Australia Ltd (2003) 204 ALR 327; [2003] FCAFC 309; BC200308121 (Jeans v CBA); Celestino v Celestino (FedCt(ACT), Spender, Miles and von Doussa JJ, 16 August 1990, unreported, BC9003531) (Celestino) at 4 and 6. Subject to these general considerations:
It will not usually be appropriate to grant leave to withdraw an admission where:

the admission relates to an allegation that is not genuinely in dispute: Coopers Brewery Ltd v Panfida Foods Ltd (1992) 26 NSWLR 738 (Panfida Foods); Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd v Bechely-Crundall (SC(NSW), Sperling J, No 10855/93, 11 June 1996, unreported) (Bechely-Crundall): Bank of Western Australia v Salmon (No 1) [2009] NSWSC 224; BC200902217 (belated withdrawal of formal admission — asserted “mistake” not intelligible or credible);

the admission has been made after obtaining relevant advice and is deliberate and clear: Panfida Foods at 745 and 748; Ness v Graffen (2003) 60 NSWLR 549 ; Drabsch v Switzerland General Insurance Co Ltd (SC(NSW), Santow J, No 3008/93, 16 October 1996, unreported, BC9604909) (Drabsch); KA & C Smith Pty Ltd v Ward (SC(NSW), Santow J, No 4464/95, 11 July 1997, unreported, BC9703097); IOL Petroleum Ltd v O’Neill (No 2) (SC(NSW), Young J, No 2334/94, 17 November 1995, unreported, BC9501842) (approved in Jeans v CBA); Apex Pallet Hire Pty Ltd v Brambles Holdings Ltd (SC(Vic), McGarvie, Marks and Ormiston JJ, 8 April 1988, unreported, BC8800750);
Leave to withdraw an admission may be appropriate where:

the application involves, in practical substance, merely the clarification or elaboration of existing traverses or other positive allegations: Matland Holdings Pty Ltd v NTZ Pty Ltd [2002] FCA 1590; BC200207787 at [48]–[52] ;
the admission flows merely from a failure to respond in a timely fashion to notices to admit pursuant to rr 17.3(2) and 17.4(2) : Bechely-Crundall; BP Australia Ltd v Carige (1992) 112 FLR 119 ;

the admission was made inadvertently or without due consideration of material matters: see Drabsch; Khouri v National Australia Bank Ltd [2007] NSWSC 987; BC200707573 (admission made without due consideration of the appropriate principles of law, application brought before the matter set down for trial); Limit (No 3) Ltd v ACE Insurance Ltd (No 2) [2009] NSWSC 1060; BC200909125 (partial withdrawal of admission made in Scott Schedule permitted — solicitor did not understand that allocated costs were included in amount admitted);

the admission has a materially altered significance as a result of subsequent changes in the proceedings: Demasi v Linfox Transport (Aust) Pty Ltd (SC(NSW), McLelland CJ in Eq, No 1076/95, 14 June 1995, unreported, BC9504816); Dome Resources at [11];

the admission is either demonstrably erroneous or relates to a matter that is likely to be the subject of substantially conflicting evidence: Maile v Rafiq [2005] NSWCA 410; BC200510054 at [97]–[104] (subsequent discovery of further evidence);
the admission was “made in confusion” and there will be no prejudice to the parties by its withdrawal: For the Good Times Pty Ltd v Coltern Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 108; BC200700735 at [5] ;

admission was made without proper legal advice: Australian and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd v Londish [2012] NSWSC 809; BC201205409 (defence filed without proper legal advice — early application to amend — real issue in dispute).

level.toc-caption: [17.2.7] Refusal of leave to withdraw admissions — examples

heading.title: Refusal of leave to withdraw admissions — examples

p.text: It will not usually be appropriate to grant leave to withdraw an admission where:

the admission relates to an allegation that is not genuinely in dispute: Coopers Brewery Ltd v Panfida Foods Ltd (1992) 26 NSWLR 738 (Panfida Foods); Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd v Bechely-Crundall (NSWSC, Sperling J, 10855 of 1993, 11 June 1996, unreported, BC9602367) (Bechely-Crundall);

the admission has been made after obtaining relevant advice and is deliberate and clear: Panfida Foods at 745 and 748; Ness v Graffen (2003) 60 NSWLR 549; Owners Corporation Strata Plan 72535 v Brookfield [2012] NSWSC 712; BC201204798 at [48]–[82] (formal admission that building work within statutory definition — no leave to withdraw ); NM Rural Enterprises Pty Ltd v Rimanui Farms Ltd [2010] NSWSC 969; BC201006380 at [10]–[14] (citing Drabsch v Switzerland General Insurance Co Ltd (NSWSC, Santow J, 16 October 1996, unreported, BC9604909) (Drabsch); even if the proposed withdrawal relates to a matter capable of genuine dispute, the party with the benefit of the admission is likely to be prejudiced by the withdrawal, either as a result of having changed its position in reliance upon the admission: H Clark (Doncaster) Ltd v Wilkinson [1965] Ch 694; [1965] 1 All ER 934 ; or as a consequence of the unavailability of evidence, or likely significant deterioration in its quality, as a result of the delay: Celestino at 4; Wyatt Gallagher Bassett at [57]–[59];

the application is made at a late stage of the proceedings: Celestino at 3 (application to withdraw liability admission on sixth day of assessment hearing refused); Jeans v CBA (application made after cross-examination at the trial refused); Essex Securities Pty Ltd v Lunt [2006] WASC 58; BC200602386 at [14], [29], and [34] (application to withdraw admission 4 years after defence filed).
Legislation cited in [17.2.9] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 17.3(2), and 17.4(2).
Leave to withdraw an admission may be appropriate where:

the application involves, in practical substance, merely the clarification or elaboration of existing traverses or other positive allegations: Matland Holdings NTZ Pty Ltd [2002] FCA 1590; BC200207787 at [48]–[52] ;
the admission flows merely from a failure to respond in a timely fashion to notices to admit pursuant to rr 17.3(2) and 17.4(2) : Bechely-Crundall ; BP Australia Ltd v Carige (1992) 112 FLR 119;

the admission was made inadvertently or without due consideration of material matters: see Drabsch ; Khouri v National Australia Bank Ltd [2007] NSWSC 987; BC200707573 (admission made without due consideration of the appropriate principles of law, application brought before the matter set down for trial); Limit (No 3) Ltd v ACE Insurance Ltd (No 2) [2009] NSWSC 1060; BC200909125 (partial withdrawal of admission made in Scott Schedule permitted — solicitor did not understand that allocated costs were included in amount admitted);

the admission has a materially altered significance as a result of subsequent changes in the proceedings: Demasi v Linfox Transport (Aust) Pty Ltd (NSWSC, McLelland CJ in Eq, 14 June 1995, unreported, BC9504816) ; Dome Resources at [11];

the admission is either demonstrably erroneous or relates to a matter that is likely to be the subject of substantially conflicting evidence: Maile v Rafiq [2005] NSWCA 410; BC200510054 at [97]–[104] (subsequent discovery of further evidence).
the admission was “made in confusion” and there will be no prejudice to the parties by its withdrawal: For the Good Times Pty Ltd v Coltern Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 108; BC200700735 at [5] .

level.toc-caption: [17.2.10] Admissions made otherwise than in the formal course of proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [17.2.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Motor Accidents Compensation Act 1999 s 81.

heading.title: Admissions made otherwise than in the formal course of proceedings

p.text: A party who has made an admission otherwise than in the formal course of the court procedure is not liable to have their pleading struck out or dismissed merely because it is inconsistent with the evidentiary admission: GIO (NSW) v Phillips (NSWCA, CA 40245 of 1992, Full Court, 27 August 1992, unreported, BC9201645); Nominal Defendant v Gabriel [2007] NSWCA 52; BC200701991 at [151] –[153]. This is so even if the admission has been made in discharge of a statutory obligation to provide a relevant notice: Nominal Defendant v Gabriel [2007] NSWCA 52; BC200701991 at [23], [111], [124] (notice under s 81 of the Motor Accidents Compensation Act 1999). In the absence of any explicit statutory provision to the contrary, such an “informal” admission cannot be formally withdrawn and has a merely evidentiary significance. The “admitting” party is entitled to dispute the accuracy of the admission. They may attempt to do so by evidence that it was influenced by mistake, misunderstanding or ignorance, or that it is otherwise inaccurate or unreliable: Nominal Defendant v Gabriel [2007] NSWCA 52; BC200701991 at [113], [144] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 17.3] r 17.3 Notice to admit facts (cf SCR Part 18, rule 2; DCR Part 15, rule 2; LCR Part 14, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Notice to admit facts (cf SCR Part 18, rule 2; DCR Part 15, rule 2; LCR Part 14, rule 2)

p.text: The requesting party may, by a notice served on the admitting party (the requesting party’s notice), require the admitting party to admit, for the purposes of the proceedings only, the facts specified in the notice.

If, as to any fact specified in the requesting party’s notice, the admitting party does not, within 14 days after service on the admitting party of the requesting party’s notice, serve on the requesting party a notice disputing that fact, that fact is, for the purposes of the proceedings only, taken to have been admitted by the admitting party in favour of the requesting party only.
The admitting party may, with the leave of the court, withdraw any such admission.
The approved form for a Notice to Admit Facts and Authenticity of Documents is Form 17 . Form 18 is the approved form for a Notice Disputing Facts and Authenticity of Documents.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 17.4] r 17.4 Notice to admit documents (cf SCR Part 18, rule 5; DCR Part 15, rule 5; LCR Part 14, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Notice to admit documents (cf SCR Part 18, rule 5; DCR Part 15, rule 5; LCR Part 14, rule 3)

p.text: The requesting party may, by a notice served on the admitting party (the requesting party’s notice), require the admitting party to admit the authenticity of the documents specified in the notice.

If, as to any document specified in the requesting party’s notice, the admitting party does not, within 14 days after service on the admitting party of the requesting party’s notice, serve on the requesting party a notice disputing the authenticity of that document, the authenticity of that document is, for the purposes of the proceedings only, taken to have been admitted by the admitting party in favour of the requesting party only.
The admitting party may, with the leave of the court, withdraw any such admission.

level.toc-caption: [17.4.5] Form of notice to admit documents

heading.title: Form of notice to admit documents

p.text: The approved form for a Notice to Admit Facts and Authenticity of Documents is Form 17 . Form 18 is the approved form for a Notice Disputing Facts and Authenticity of Documents.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 17.5] r 17.5 Admission of documents discovered (cf SCR Part 18, rule 4; DCR Part 15, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Admission of documents discovered (cf SCR Part 18, rule 4; DCR Part 15, rule 4)

p.text: In this rule:
means the party on whom a list of documents is served under rule 21.3 .
means the party by whom a list of documents is served under rule 21.3.
[subr (1) subst Amendment 6 of 2005 r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 9 December 2005 ]

If a requesting party allows inspection of any documents referred to in a list of documents under rule 21.5 , the admitting party is taken to have made the following admissions in favour of the requesting party, unless the court orders otherwise:
in respect of each document described in the list as an original document, that the document is an original document and was printed, written, signed or executed as it purports to have been,
in respect of each document described in the list as a copy of an original document, that the document is a true copy.
[subr (2) am Amendment 6 of 2005 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 9 December 2005]
Subrule (2) does not apply to a document referred to in the list of documents if the admitting party:
has, by his or her pleading, denied the authenticity of the document, or

has served on the requesting party, within 14 days after the time limited under rule 21.5 for inspection of a document, a notice to the effect that the admitting party disputes the authenticity of the document.

The admitting party and the requesting party are taken to be in the same position as they would have been in had the admitting party, on the date of service of the list of documents, served on the requesting party a notice requiring production at the trial of such of the documents specified in the list as are in the possession of the requesting party.
[subr (4) am Amendment 6 of 2005 r 2 and Sch 1[4], effective 9 December 2005]

level.toc-caption: [17.5.5] Production of discovered documents at trial

p.text: Legislation cited in [17.5.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 21.1.

heading.title: Production of discovered documents at trial

p.text: The object of this rule is to achieve the effect of a notice to produce documents and a notice to admit authenticity of documents without the formality of serving such notices. For discovery, see rr 21.1 and following. The effect of the rule is that a party who disputes the authenticity of a document discovered by another party should give notice of the dispute within 14 days after the time limited for inspection.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 17.6] r 17.6 Restricted effect of admission (cf SCR Part 18, rule 6; DCR Part 15, rule 6; LCR Part 14, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Restricted effect of admission (cf SCR Part 18, rule 6; DCR Part 15, rule 6; LCR Part 14, rule 6)

p.text: An admission made under this Part in connection with any proceedings:
may not be used in those proceedings except in favour of the party in whose favour it was made, and
is taken to have been made for the purposes of those proceedings only.

This rule limits the availability of any admission made under this Part to the party in whose favour it is made, and to “the purposes of those proceedings only” in which the admission has been made. This permissible use of the admission includes interlocutory applications, the trial and any appeal. It also includes any new trial that might be ordered. An admission made under these rules is not available as evidence in any subsequent proceedings: British Thomson-Houston Co Ltd v British Insulated and Helsby Cables Ltd [1924] 1 Ch 203 at 210 (on appeal); British Thomson-Houston Co Ltd v British Insulated and Helsby Cables Ltd [1924] 2 Ch 160 ; Re Walters; Neison v Walters (1889) 61 LT 872.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 17.7] r 17.7 Judgment on admissions (cf SCR Part 18, rule 3; DCR Part 15, rule 3; LCR Part 14, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Judgment on admissions (cf SCR Part 18, rule 3; DCR Part 15, rule 3; LCR Part 14, rule 5)

p.text: If admissions are made by a party, whether by his or her pleadings or otherwise, the court may, on the application of any other party, give any judgment or make any order to which the other party is entitled on the admissions.
The court may exercise its powers under this rule even if the other questions in the proceedings have not been determined.
Legislation cited in [17.7.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 87.

A person may be expressly authorised to make admissions on behalf of a party. Such an authority is necessarily conferred upon the person who verifies pleadings, answers interrogatories or responds to notices to admit facts on behalf of a party. Implied authority to make admissions may also exist where a person is acting in the ordinary course of their employment. For example, a managing director may have authority to make out of court admissions on behalf of a party: Fraser Henleins Pty Ltd v Cody (1945) 70 CLR 100; [1945] ALR 186 . While it is permissible to seek admissions from a party in cross-examination, it is not really appropriate to attempt, in the course of taking evidence, to elicit admissions from a witness who is an employee of a party. This is because any implied authority that the witness might otherwise have to make admissions in the ordinary course of employment does not extend to confer a similar authority to make admissions in the course of giving evidence in court: Bond Media Ltd v John Fairfax Group Pty Ltd (1988) 16 NSWLR 82; 14 ACLR 701; BC8801286 ; Shears v Chisholm [1994] 2 VR 535; (1992) 9 ACSR 691 (admissions made in evidence in earlier proceedings involving company not admissible against directors in subsequent proceedings). See, however, Evidence Act 1995 s 87 in relation to the admission of hearsay statements made by agents.
Legislation cited in [17.7.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 16.3.

Although admissions may be either express or implied, they must be clear if they are to found a judgment: Ellis v Allen [1914] 1 Ch 904 at 909; [1911–13] All ER Rep 906 ; Ash v Hutchinson & Co (Publishers) Ltd [1936] Ch 489 at 503; [1936] 2 All ER 1496 . The failure of a defendant to file and serve a defence constitutes a default that may give rise to an entitlement to judgment under r 16.3 of the UCPR. It does not, however, give rise to a deemed admission and permit judgment to be entered under the present rule: MY Distributors Pty Ltd v Omaq Pty Ltd (1992) 36 FCR 578 .
Admissions made in criminal proceedings may be relied upon in subsequent civil proceedings: Adams v ETA Foods Ltd (1987) 19 FCR 93; 78 ALR 611 .
Legislation cited in [17.7.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 14.26.

Admissions may be made expressly in the pleadings. They may also be made impliedly — for example, a plea that the effect of a particular document is not correctly set out in the opposing pleading constitutes an admission of the existence and authenticity of the document and judgment on admission may be given if the document is produced and establishes the claim made: Barnard v Wieland (1882) 30 WR 947; cf Rutter v Tregent (1879) 12 Ch D 758 ; Smith v Davies (1884) 28 Ch D 650 . Admissions may also be made by a failure to plead — because any failure to traverse an allegation has effect as an admission, except in the case of allegations against a person under legal disability: r 14.26 . Admissions may even be made (where a pleading is struck out) by failure to file an amended pleading.

Admissions may be made informally (ie, otherwise than in documents that formally record the contested issues in the proceedings, for example, orally: Re Beeny; Ffrench v Sproston [1894] 1 Ch 499 ) and they may be relied upon whether they have been made either before or after the proceedings were instituted: Hampden v Wallis (1884) 27 Ch D 251 ; Porrett v White (1885) 31 Ch D 52 ; Neville v Matthewman [1894] 3 Ch 345; [1894] 63 LJ Ch 734 ; Ellis v Allen [1914] 1 Ch 904; [1911–13] All ER Rep 906 ). Where an admission is alleged to have been made otherwise than in a pleading, a party moving under this rule will have to establish both the fact and the terms of the admission. This may necessitate proof of matters constituting the background circumstances to the making of the alleged admission: Kelly v Mawson [1981] 1 NSWLR 184 at 187; (1981) 5 ACLR 600 ; cf Re Registered Trademarks “Certina” (1970) 44 ALJR 191 ; Ellis v Allen, above. Irrespective of the particular manner in which an informal admission has been made, a distinction must be drawn between its admissibility and its probative weight. An informal admission is admissible against a party notwithstanding that the person making the admission had no direct knowledge of the truth of the matters admitted and relied upon the statement of others, or upon inferences from the circumstances. But the ultimate probative force of an admission must be determined by reference to the circumstances in which it was made. If the person who made the informal admission in fact had no relevant knowledge, the probative force of the admission must be regarded as slight: Lustre Hosiery Ltd v York (1935) 54 CLR 134 at 138; 9 ALJR 314 ; Bond Media Ltd v John Fairfax Group Pty Ltd (1988) 16 NSWLR 82; 14 ACLR 701; BC8801286 ; Trade Practices Commission v TNT Management Pty Ltd (1984) 56 ALR 647 ; RW Miller and Co Pty Ltd v Krupp (Aust) Pty Ltd (1991) 32 NSWLR 152 .

The court will commonly grant the relief that the admissions properly justify — particularly if the application is based on an admission formally made in the proceedings and the admission is clear in its terms: Ash v Hutchinson & Co (Publishers) Ltd [1936] Ch 489 at 503; [1936] 2 All ER 1496 ; Frinty v Landmax Developments (2010) 272 ALR 412; [2010] NSWSC 734; BC201004925 (loan admitted in defence — no pleaded defence of repayment — judgment in favour of the plaintiff).

But a court is not bound to act on the admissions: Termijtelen v Van Arkel [1974] 1 NSWLR 525 at 528 ; Kelly v Mawson [1981] 1 NSWLR 184 at 185; (1981) 5 ACLR 600 . If the asserted admission has been made informally, the court may take into account the circumstances of its making, and make its own assessment of the significance of the admission: see [17.7.25]. The court should not order judgment on an admission if it appears that the judgment is contested and the asserted admission is contrary to the true facts: Termijtelen v Van Arkel , above; Re Wright; Kirke v North [1895] 2 Ch 747 at 750 ; Williams v Powell [1894] WN 141 ; Gramophone Co Ltd v Magazine Holder Co (1911) 28 RPC 221 at 225–7

Judgment may be given for the admitted part of a claim, without prejudice to the plaintiff proceeding in respect of the balance of the claim: Re Leymar Constructions Pty Ltd and the Companies Act (NSWSC, Needham J, 27 October 1980, unreported); Lancashire Welders Ltd v Harland & Wolff Ltd [1950] 2 All ER 1096.

level.toc-caption: [17.7.40] Pleadings and evidence in other proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [17.7.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 14.23, r 14.24.

heading.title: Pleadings and evidence in other proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [17.7.45] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Defamation Act 2005 s 20.

An apology made in defamation proceedings does not constitute an admission and is not admissible as evidence of fault or liability in relation to the publication of allegedly defamatory material: Defamation Act 2005 s 20 .
